A new catalytic system based on copper supported on poly(N-vinylimidazole-co-N-vinylcaprolactam) was investigated. Various compositions of copolymers were checked to compare their influence on the catalytic activity. Copolymer with 25 mol% of N-vinylimidazole and 75 mol% of N-vinylcaprolactam showed the best catalytic efficiency along with its recycling ability in the click reaction and Chan-Lam coupling. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords N-vinylimidazole polymers Copper catalysis Click reaction Chan-Lam coupling Recycling Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Formation of the Csp2-N bond was always the focus of chemical research due to the possibility of making compounds for industrial application, medicine, and various fields of human activity. The key role in the development of the synthesis of such organic compounds was played by catalysis. Palladium catalysis ensured the transition from Ullmann chemistry [1,2], which requires severe conditions (i.e. temperatures up to 200 °C and more than an equimolar amount of copper) to form the Csp2-N bond to cross-coupling reactions using a catalytic amount of palladium complexes with phosphine or carbene ligands [3,4]. Naturally, from the point of view of green chemistry, such a process has shortcomings: it is expensive and toxic. Therefore, the return on a new round to catalysis by copper (salts, oxides, nanoparticles) in combination with non-toxic N,N-, N,O, O,O- ligands found exceptionally wide application in a wide variety of reactions [5–11] and became basically the Renaissance of Ullmann chemistry. These reactions include reactions catalyzed by Cu(I) and Cu(II): the click reaction of azides with alkynes to form triazoles [12] and the Chan-Lam reaction [13–15], in which oxidative coupling occurs between arylboronic acids and amines, i.e. between two nucleophiles. Usefulness of this reaction is also proved to be high due to the fact that it occurs under mild conditions and in the absence of ligands. Both reactions have already found wide application in organic synthesis [16,17], and for both, especially for the click reaction, a wide variety of catalysts have been proposed, including recyclable nanocopper catalysts on various supports [18–20]. However, the search for more efficient recyclable catalysts leading to high product yields under mild conditions and in eco-friendly solvents continues successfully [21–25]. The purpose of this work was to use for these reactions a catalyst supported by a soft matrix of an amphiphilic polymer, which would make it easy to separate it from the product and reuse. Polymers of N-vinylimidazole (VI), due to their basic properties, as well as their ability to coordinate with various metal atoms, are often used as catalysts of various organic reactions. For example, copolymers of VI with N-vinylcaprolactam (VCL) catalyze the addition of various nucleophiles to Michael acceptors [26–28], catalyze organic multicomponent reactions [29], acetylation of alcohols, thiols and amines [30,31], aldol condensation [32]. In addition, such polymers act as enzyme analogues, catalyzing the hydrolysis of esters [33–38]. Their zinc complexes are considered to be analogues of carbonic anhydrase [39]. Along with the analogues of enzymes, complexes of VI-containing polymers with copper(II) ions, behaving like tyrosinase enzymes, are also of interest [40–42]. Recently, vinylimidazole polymers have started to be used for production of recyclable catalysts for cross-coupling, oxidation and addition reactions [43–49]. Earlier in our laboratory, we studied the use of copolymers of VI and VCL in catalysis. The advantage of such VI-VCL copolymers is their solubility in aqueous medium, where they exhibit a lower critical solution temperature (LCST) and undergo a coil-to-globule transition. In addition to LCTS, copolymers tend to form globular aggregates due to hydrophobic association of globules. Hydrophobic reagents are concentrated in such aggregates resulting in an increased reaction rate by several orders of magnitude. Surface nanolayer aggregates can be considered as catalytic nanoreactors. An increase in the reaction rate due to concentration of the substrate on the hydrophobic-hydrophilic interface of aggregates is in agreement with the results of theoretical analysis of the role of this interface in catalytic properties [50,51]. Recently, we have shown that these copolymers enable stabilization of palladium nanoparticles, and the resulting catalysts effectively catalyze Heck and Suzuki reactions and the cyanation of aryl halides [52–55]. So far, these copolymers are used in palladium and organic catalysis. In this paper, we showed that copolymers of VI and VCL can be successfully used for copper catalysis. Efficiency of a copper catalyst significantly depends on composition of a copolymer. The click reaction and oxidative coupling of arylboronic acids with azoles (Chan-Lam reaction) were used as models for this study. 2 Experimental 2.1 General remarks N-Vinylcaprolactam (VCL, 98%, Sigma-Aldrich) and N-Vinylimidazole (VI, ≥99%, Sigma-Aldrich) were twice distilled under vacuum (0.1 mbar) prior to the experiment. α,α,'-Azoisobutyronitrile (AIBN, 98%, Merck) was twice recrystallized from methanol and dried under vacuum at room temperature. Benzyl azides, [1-(O-ethylxanthyl) ethyl]benzene (EXEB) were obtained according to the literature methods [56,57]. Commercially available compounds (arylboronic acids, benzyl bromides, arylalkynes, azoles) were used without additional purification. Cu K-edge XAFS spectra were measured using Structural Materials Science beamline of the Kurchatov Synchrotron Radiation Source (National Research Center "Kurchatov Institute", Moscow) in the transmission mode using ionization chambers filled with N2/Ar mixture as a detector and Si(111) channel-cut monochromator. Standard data processing protocol was used. FT-IR spectra of PVI25 and Cu/PVI25 complex were recorded on Bruker Vertex 70v FTIR Spectrometer (Germany) in attenuated total reflection (ATR) mode using a PIKE GladyATR device with diamond ATR unit. Elemental analysis was performed using CHBS/O analyzer, Perkin Elmer Series II 2400. The 1H NMR spectra were recorded on 600 MHz Avance or 400 MHz Avance II (Bruker, Germany) spectrometers. Molecular weight characteristics (Mn, Mw, and Mw/Mn) of the copolymers were measured by gel permeation chromatography (GPC, Agilent 1200) coupled with an RI detector and PLmixC column. 0.03 M LiCl in 1-methylpirrolidone was used as the eluent at 50 °С at a flow rate of 0.5 ml/min. Polystyrene standards were used for calibration. The microstructure of the samples was studied by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) using Hitachi SU8000 field-emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM). Target-oriented approach was utilized for the optimization of the analytic measurements. Before measurements, the samples were fixed on a 25 mm aluminum specimen stub by conductive carbon plasticine-like adhesive and coated with a 15 nm film of carbon. Images were acquired in secondary electron mode at 5 kV accelerating voltage. Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX-SEM) studies were carried out using Oxford Instruments X-max 80 EDS system at 20 kV accelerating voltage. Dioxane (DO), chloroform, tetrahydrofuran (THF), dimethylformamide (DMF) were purified via conventional methods. Deionized (DI) water was obtained by a Milli-Q reverse osmosis system. 2.2 Synthesis of (co)polymers Poly(N-vinylcaprolactam) (PVCL), poly(N-vinylimidazole) (PVI) and copolymers of VCL and VI with various composition and molecular weight were prepared by both free-radical (co)polymerization and reversible addition-fragmentation chain transfer (RAFT) of VCL and/or VI. The reaction conditions and copolymers characteristics are given in Table 1 . 2.2.1 Preparation of PVCL The solution of freshly distilled VCL (1.94 g, 13.94 mmol) in DO was degassed for 30 min at stirring under Ar atmosphere. AIBN (3.2 mg, 0.019 mmol) was added to the reaction mixture that was degassed for further 30 min under Ar atmosphere. The mixture was then heated in Ar flow with stirring at 60 °C for 4 h. The reaction mixture was solved in THF and then precipitated into ether. The PVCL powder was filtered off through a glass filter and washed with ether and dried under reduced pressure to give PVCL in 80% yield. Fig. S3 shows 1H NMR spectrum of PVCL. The signals at 4.29–4.16 ppm due to CH-group of backbone, the chemical shifts at 3.16 ppm and 2.37, 2.19 ppm characterize protons of NCH2 - and COCH2-groups of caprolactam ring. The signal at 1.97–0.98 ppm refers to -CH2 of backbone and NCCH2CH2 of caprolactam ring. 2.2.2 Preparation of PVI25 Freshly distilled VCL (5.36 g, 38.51 mmol), and VI (0.65 g, 6.91 mmol) were degassed for 30 min at stirring under Ar atmosphere. AIBN (9.9 mg, 0.06 mmol) was added to the reaction mixture that was degassed for further 30 min under Ar atmosphere. The mixture was then heated in Ar flow with stirring at 60 °C for 2 h. The viscous reaction mixture was solved in chloroform and then precipitated into petroleum ether. The PVI25 powder was filtered off through a glass filter and washed with ether and dried under reduced pressure to give PVI25 in 52% yield. 1H NMR (ppm, D2O): δ = 7.62–6.89 (m, 3 H), 4.14 (s, 1 H), 3.79–3.02 (m, 3 H), 2.34–2.19 (m, 2 H), 1.52–1.45 (m, 8 H) (Fig. 4). The broad signals (8, 9 and 10) at 7.62–6.53 ppm belong to the protons of imidazole ring of VI units. The signal (1) at 4.42–3.94 ppm and big signals (2.5 and 6) at 1.45 ppm refer to one proton of -CH-group of PVCL backbone, to four protons of –CH2-groups of the backbone of both PNCL and PVI and to six protons of –CH2-groups in caprolactam ring, respectively. The signal (3) with chemical shifts at 2.34–2.19 (-COCH2-) and the signals (4 and 7) between 3.95 and 2.56 ppm (-NCH2, -NCCH2CH2CH2) due to caprolactam ring and -CH-group of VI units in copolymer backbone. 2.2.3 Preparation of PVI60 Freshly distilled VCL (4.69 g, 33.69 mmol), and VI (1.38 g, 14.66 mmol) were degassed for 30 min at stirring under Ar atmosphere. AIBN (11.6 mg, 0.067 mmol) was added to the reaction mixture that was degassed for further 30 min under Ar atmosphere. The mixture was then heated in Ar flow with stirring at 60 °C for 4 h. The reaction mixture was solved in chloroform and then precipitated into cyclohexane. The PVI60 powder was filtered off through the glass filter, washed with ether, and dried under reduced pressure to give PVI60 in 17% yield. 1H NMR (ppm, D2O): δ = 7.53–6.81 (m, 3 H), 4.21 (s, 1 H), 3.80–2.69 (m, 3 H), 2.14 (m, 2 H), 1.48 (m, 8 H) (Fig. S5). 2.2.4 Preparation of PVI90 Freshly distilled VCL (3.01 g, 21.62 mmol), and VI (3.07 g, 32.62 mmol) were degassed for 30 min at stirring under Ar atmosphere. AIBN (12.9 mg, 0.079 mmol) was added to the reaction mixture that was degassed for further 30 min under Ar atmosphere. The mixture was then heated in Ar flow with stirring at 60 °C for 4 h. The reaction mixture was solved in chloroform and then precipitated into cyclohexane. The PVI90 powder was filtered off through a glass filter and washed with ether and dried under reduced pressure to give PVI90 in 10% yield. 1H NMR (ppm, D2O): δ = 7.20–6.76 (m, 3 H), 4.10 (s, 1 H), 3.69–2.64 (m, 3 H), 2.04 (m, 2 H), 1.46 (m, 8 H) (Fig. S6). 2.2.5 Preparation of PVI49 Freshly distilled VCL (3.48 g, 25.00 mmol), and VI (1.01 g, 10.73 mmol) were degassed for 30 min at stirring under Ar atmosphere. AIBN (8.4 mg, 0.051 mmol) was added to the reaction mixture that was degassed for further 30 min under Ar atmosphere. The mixture was then heated in Ar flow with stirring at 60 °C for 3.75 h. The reaction mixture was solved in chloroform and then precipitated into hexane. The PVI49 powder was filtered off through a glass filter and washed with ether and dried under reduced pressure to give PVI49 in 14% yield. 1H NMR (ppm, D2O): δ = 7.50–6.80 (m, 3 H), 4.14 (s, 1 H), 3.77–2.70 (m, 3 H), 2.11 (m, 2 H), 1.45 (m, 8 H) (Fig. S7). 2.2.6 Preparation of PVI85 Freshly distilled VCL (4.12 g, 29.59 mmol), and VI (2.29 g, 24.33 mmol) were degassed for 30 min at stirring under Ar atmosphere. AIBN (11.2 mg, 0.068 mmol) was added to the reaction mixture that was degassed for further 30 min under Ar atmosphere. The mixture was then heated in Ar flow with stirring at 60 °C for 4 h. The reaction mixture was solved in chloroform and then precipitated into cyclohexane. The PVI85 powder was filtered off through a glass filter and washed with ether and dried under reduced pressure to give PVI85 in 21% yield.1H NMR (ppm, D2O): δ = 7.40–6.79 (m, 3 H), 4.15 (s, 1 H), 3.73–2.70 (m, 3 H), 2.08 (m, 2 H), 1.47 (m, 8 H) (Fig. S8). 2.2.7 Preparation of PVI by RAFT polymerization Freshly distilled VI (6.62 g, 70.34 mmol), EXEB (0.045 g, 0.20 mmol), AIBN (0.01, 0.06 mmol) were placed in a Schlenk flask equipped with a magnetic stirrer. The solution was degassed by three freeze-thaw evacuation cycles and heated at 60 °C on an oil bath for 20 h. The polymerization was quenched in liquid nitrogen. The PVI sample were precipitated in hexane, washed with acetone and freeze-dried. Fig. S9 shows the 1H NMR spectrum of PVI in D2O. In this spectrum, the signals corresponding to the backbone protons appear between 1.85 and 3.69 ppm, while the signals between 6.96 and 6.53 ppm belong to the three protons in the imidazole ring. As for the EXEB units, only the signals of methyl protons (9 and 11) can be well seen at 0.95 ppm. Other signals of EXEB cannot be observed due to their overlapping with the signals of VI units and their weak intensity. The signal at 2.2 ppm corresponds to the inclusion of acetone, the washing solvent, in PVI. 2.2.8 Preparation of PVI15 by RAFT polymerization PVI15 was prepared by RAFT polymerization of VI initiated with AIBN in the presence of macro-transfer agent PVCL-RAFT-agent (M n = 13,400, M w/M n = 1.52). PVI15 diblock copolymer was prepared applying a similar procedure to that employed in the PVI homopolymer preparation. The procedure is described as follows: the PVCL-RAFT-agent (0.54 g, 0.04 mmol), VI (0.44 g, 4.68 mmol), AIBN (0.84 mg, 0.005 mmol) and 1.66 mL of DMF were added into Schlenk flask equipped with a magnetic stirrer. The solution was degassed by three freeze-draw evacuation cycles and heated at 60 °C on oil bath for 46 h. The products were purified by dialysis against deionized water and isolated by lyophilization. 1H NMR (ppm, D2O): δ = 7.25–6.51 (m, 8 H), 4.27–4.14 (s, 1 H), 3.62–3.06 (m, 3 H), 2.35–2.00 (m, 2 H), 1.66–1.56 (m, 14 H) (Fig. S10). 2.3 Synthesis of Cu/PVI25 complex Polymer PVI25 (62.4 mg) was dissolved in deionized water (4 ml), then 0.025 M of CuSO4·5H2O solution was added (1.2 mL). After stirring at room temperature for 30 min solution was gently evaporated under reduced pressure. The residue washed by water and THF and dried to give Cu/PVI25 as blue powder (64 mg). 2.4 General procedure for Cu/PVI25-catalysed Huisgen reaction of alkynes with alkylazides Polymer PVI25 (1.3 mg) was dissolved in solution of CuSO4·5H2O in H2O (0.00125 M, 0.5 mL) at stirring in 8 mL glass tube with Teflon cap. After dissolving the polymer, alkyl azide (0.25 mmol), alkyne (0.3 mmol), sodium ascorbate (5 mg) and THF (0.5 mL) were added into the tube. The mixture was stirred at 50 °C for 3 h. After cooling, the product was separated by extraction with EtOAc, evaporated, purified by flash chromatography and analyzed by 1H NMR spectroscopy. The catalyst was separated by decantation and used in the next run of recycling experiments. 2.5 General procedure for Cu/PVI25-catalyzed Chan-Lam coupling of arylboronic acids with azoles Cu(OAc)2·H2O (2.5 mg) and polymer PVI25 (12.8 mg) were mixed in MeOH (2 mL) in 10 mL flask and then corresponding boronic acid (0.25 mmol), azole (0.3 mmol) and molecular sieves 3 Å (50 mg) were added. The mixture was stirred at 50 °C under dry air for the time, as per Table 5. Then reaction mixture was evaporated and the product was extracted with petroleum ether, evaporated, purified by flash chromatography and analyzed using 1H NMR spectroscopy. The residue after extraction was used in the next catalytic run. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis of copolymers Initially, we prepared copolymers of VCL and VI with various compositions and molecular weight by free-radical polymerization of VCL and VI in bulk. Copolymerization was run at 60 °C in argon atmosphere in the presence of AIBN, [AIBN] = 1.1·10−2 mol/l) as an initiator. The reaction conditions and polymer characteristics are given in Table 1. The composition of copolymers was determined by 1H NMR. Molecular weight characteristics (Mn and Mw/Mn) of (co)polymers were estimated by gel permeation chromatography using 0.03 M LiCl in N-methylpyrrolidone as eluent. All prepared (co)polymers were used further as support in copper-catalyzed reactions. 3.2 Huisgen 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition To investigate practical application of copolymers of VI and VCL in catalysis, we began to explore an important example of the reaction for synthesis of various biologically active compounds as [3 + 2]-cycloaddition of azides to terminal alkynes. The reaction of p-nitrobenzylazide with phenylacetylene was studied in a mixture of water-THF in the presence of triethylamine as a base (Table 2 ). As precatalyst, we used copper sulfate (1 mol%) and copolymers VI and VCL (the amount required for the ratio Cu/VI = 1/4). In the initial experiments, we found that homopolymers and VCL/VI copolymers, such as diblock copolymer PVI15 and copolymer PVI90 were significantly less active than the copolymers with a high molecular weight PVI25-85, which for 1 h reaction resulted in 100% triazole yield. For these polymers, we checked the need of the use of triethylamine. It turned out that in the case of polymers PVI49, PVI60, and PVI85, a significant decrease in the rate of formation of triazole was observed during the reaction without triethylamine. At the same time, PVI25 polymer retains high catalytic activity without a base. In this case, apparently, the polymers serve as bases, but the basicity depends significantly on the composition. Furthermore, we found out that PVI25 polymer can be used in catalysis in the presence of only 0.1 mol% of copper, with the reaction ending in 6 h; with 0.025 mol% of copper the reaction was completed after 40 h. The observed effect of the composition of PVI25-85 copolymers (Entries 11–14, Table 2) on the catalytic activity in the reaction without triethylamine can be explained as follows. It is known that thermosensitive polymers can either undergo phase separation or form globular aggregates with a core-shell structure at temperatures above LCST of the thermosensitive component. PVCL is also well-known as a thermoresponsive polymer, exhibiting LCST at 33–34 °C [58]. In the case of globular aggregates, thermosensitive polymers exhibit increased catalytic activity in the esterolysis of an amphiphilic substrate [59–61]. In [62–65], it is reported that the catalytic activity of the "protein–like" fraction of copolymers VCL with VI obtained by radical polymerization in aqueous systems above phase transition temperatures has been studied. The "protein-like" fractions did not precipitate from aqueous solutions when heated, but underwent a cooperative coil-globule transition with the formation of globular aggregates. The soluble fraction of the VCL and VI copolymers (M w = 40 kDa, [VCL]/[VI] = 73/27 mol% and M w = 120 kDa, [VCL]/[VI] = 61.5/38.5 mol%) in the protein-like conformation showed increased catalytic activity in the esterolysis of p-nitrophenyl propionate (NPP) [62]. Recently, we synthesized diblock copolymers VCL and VI by two-stage RAFT polymerization and investigated their thermosensitive and catalytic properties [33,34,37]. It was shown that these diblock copolymers form micelle-like mesoglobules in the temperature range preceding the phase separation temperature. In addition, in the specified temperature range, there is a significant increase in the catalytic activity of copolymers with respect to the hydrolysis of NPP due to the formation of highly developed hydrophilic-hydrophobic interfaces inside the mesoglobules. It is obvious that during the formation of complexes with copper ions, a conformational rearrangement of thermosensitive copolymers VCL and VI can occur with the formation of globular aggregates with a core-shell structure. The hydrophobic core of such aggregates is formed by sequences of VCL units, and the hydrophilic shell is formed by sequences of VI units. This phenomenon is explained by a change in the balance of hydrophobic interactions and hydration near the θ-conditions of PVCL, which contributes to the collapse and aggregation of polymers. The composition of copolymers and their molecular weight clearly also influence this process. We assume that the PVI25 copolymer, due to its structure (molecular weight, composition), shows the greatest tendency to form such aggregates than other polymers. The formation of micelle-like aggregates from PVI25 with a high local concentration of VI links on the surface of aggregates may explain the increased basicity of the catalyst. This self-assembly of copper ions and polymer PVI25 is insoluble in the reaction medium and can be easily separated from the reaction products through filtration. The catalyst retains catalytic activity for at least 5 catalytic cycles (Fig. 1 ). In the reaction mixtures, after the separation of the catalyst, the presence of copper was not observed, as shown by the ICP-MS. To postulate the heterogeneous nature of catalysis by material PVI25, we used hot filtration method. After 1 h of the reaction, the catalyst was removed; evolution of the reaction mixture was monitored by 1H NMR spectroscopy, showing no reaction progress without the catalyst. The Cu/PVI25 complexes obtained before the reaction and generated in the reaction after five runs were isolated and freeze-dried. The powders obtained were investigated using Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), element analysis and X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XANES, EXAFS), SEM and SEM-EDX. Fig. 2 shows the FTIR spectra of PVI25 copolymer (Fig. 2, 1) and Cu/PVI25 complexes prepared before reaction (Fig. 2, 2) and generated in the reaction (Fig. 2, 3). In Fig. 2, 1, the peak at 3108 cm−1 corresponds to the stretching vibrations of CH from the imidazole ring [66], two bands at 2917 and 2850 cm−1 corresponds to the CH stretching (backbone chain and caprolactam ring) vibrations [67–68] . The intense absorption peak at 1620 cm−1 was assigned to the stretching vibration of the carbonyl group in the caprolactam ring and to the stretching vibration of aromatic C=C bands [69,70], the peaks at 1483 and 1433 cm−1 corresponding to the stretching vibrations of aromatic C=N and CN bonds, and a signal at 1227 cm−1 due to the NCN bond [70].The peaks at 1260 and 1160 cm−1 that belong to the C–N stretching vibrations from NVCL [70]. It can be seen from the spectra of Cu/PVI25 complexes (Fig. 2, 2), that specific imidazole ring peaks in complex at 3125 cm−1 (C=CH/N=CH stretching) and at 1234 cm−1(ring vibration) shift to the higher wavenumbers as compared to PVI25 copolymer. The result may be due to an increase in the rigidity of the imidazole ring resulting from interactions with Cu ions. FTIR spectra of Cu/PVI25 complexes exhibited new peak at 1038 cm−1. The band at 1038 cm−1 is ascribed to the in-plane symmetric ring stretching of imidazole in the complexes [71]. In order to estimate the amount of VI units connected with Cu ions, elemental analysis for carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, and copper content in preformed and used in the reaction Cu/PVI25 powders was performed. Theoretical contents of C, H, N, and Cu elements were calculated on the assumption that Cu(II) ions coordinated by nitrogen atoms of four VI units in PVI25 [71]. It is seen that for Cu/PVI25 complexes, the percentage of C, H, N, and Cu elements are 57.85, 8.11, 11.12 and 3.2 and 58.08, 7.79, 11.07 and 3.3%, respectively, which is almost the same as the theoretical values: 66.05 (C), 8.54 (H), 13.29 (N), and 3.1% (Cu). Elemental analysis results showed that the preferred coordination number of Cu in both Cu/PVI25 complexes was four, namely, one copper ion coordinated four VI units. The coordination number obtained is in agreement with the previous report [40]. Zhang et al. found that the stoichiometric ratio between the imidazole groups in poly(N-vinylimidazole) and the copper ions was four [40]. The quantitative estimation of the surface elements of the Cu/PVI25 powders prepared before the reaction and generated in the reaction, performed using SEM-EDХ measurements, gives similar results (Fig. 3 ). Atomic percentage of elements from SEM-EDХ spectroscopy of the Cu/PVI25 complexes is shown in the inserts of the Fig. 3a,b. The SEM-EDХ spectra of the Cu/PVI25 complexes (Fig. 3) reveal the presence of S (from CuSO4) and Si elements. The presence of Si is due to the fluorescence detector. The experimental Cu K-edge XANES spectrum for the Cu-filled polymer is shown in Fig. 4 , left panel together with similarly measured spectra of the reference spectra, i.e., CuSO4·5H2O and CuO. As it can be seen from the figure, the energy position of absorption edge for the polymer sample denotes that Cu/PVI25 is exactly the same as in the two reference spectra. This clearly means that copper ions remain in the +2 oxidation state, which is probably related to the easy oxidation of Cu+ during isolation of the catalyst from the reaction mixture. The coordination polyhedron of Cu(II) is most probably a Jahn-Teller distorted octahedron formed by oxygen atoms. Further details on the local structure parameters can be gained from EXAFS part of EXAFS spectra as shown in Fig. 4 (right panel). The Fourier Transform is dominated by a single peak attributed to Cu-O bonds. The experimental spectrum is well simulated by two Cu-O components, viz., 4 shorter distances of 1.97 A and 2 longer distances of 2.26 A, which fall into a typical range of octahedral Cu(II) oxo-complexes. It should be noted that the experimental Fourier Transform does not reveal any intense peaks at longer distances. It indicates that Cu ions form isolated species coordinated to active sites of the polymer matrix rather than polynuclear clusters or nanoparticles of specific inorganic phases. The morphology of the Cu/PVI25 powders prepared before the reaction and generated in the reaction was characterized using SEM. The SEM images are shown in Fig. 5 . It can be seen that Cu/PVI25 powders prepared before reaction (Fig. 5a,b) has an elongated aggregate structure with diameter ranged from 0.5 to 1 μm. The observed elongated aggregates can be explained by the transformation of micelle-like aggregates from PVI25 under conditions of binding to copper. It can be seen from the Fig. 5c,d that the Cu/PVI25 complex generated in the reaction and used in several cycles has a porous structure with a pore size ranged from about 1 to 5 μm. Different morphology of preformed catalyst and catalyst after reuse can be explained by rearrangement due to reduction of copper ion under the reaction conditions. To prove that the reduction of Cu(II) by sodium ascorbate takes place, we investigated catalyst Cu/PVI25 by UV-vis spectroscopy. The disappearance of the characteristic signal of Cu(II) was observed after addition of sodium ascorbate (see SI, Fig. S11). At the same time, the reaction did not proceed in the absence of sodium ascorbate. Both the preformed Cu/PVI25 material and catalyst generated in situ by mixing of polymer PVI25 and copper sulfate were showed similar catalytic activity. Because of application of prepared in situ catalysts is more convenient we further used such a system to investigate the scope of click-reaction. Catalyst based on PVI25 was used in the synthesis of the series of triazoles starting from different alkylazides and terminal alkynes bearing both electrondonating and electronwithdrawing groups. In all cases, we observed almost quantitative yields of the products using 0.25 mol% of catalyst (Table 3 ). 3.3 Chan-Lam coupling Chan-Lam coupling reaction of arylboronic acids or their esters with different nucleophiles, is one of the most applicable copper-catalyzed reactions. This reaction allows to form a range CC and C-heteroatom bonds under mild conditions (often at room temperature) [72]. Chan-Lam coupling is very convenient for the preparation of arylated heterocycles, including biologically active ones [73]. Herein, we propose to explore our abovementioned copper/copolymer self-assemblies in the reaction of arylboronic acids with a series of azoles such as imidazole, pyrazole and benzotriazole as efficient recyclable catalysts. Firstly, we optimized reaction conditions by trial coupling of p-tolylboronic acid and imidazole (Table 4 ). The most active polymer PVI25 in click reaction was also active here, but when using a mixture water/organic solvents we observed formation of phenol (up to 21%, entries 1–3). In methanol the reaction proceeds faster and phenol is formed in a small amount (entry 5). Among the catalysts like in the previous reaction, PVI25 was more active than the others (entries 6–8). Finally, the addition of molecular sieves 3 Å allowed to avoid phenol formation (entry 10). Catalyst is recyclable at least for 5 consecutive runs without any drop of activity (Fig. 6 ). In optimized conditions, we checked different arylboronic acids in the reaction with imidazole (Table 5 ). Completion of reactions in the case of arylboronic acids with electron-donating group was observed after 4 h, but electron-deficient arylboronic acids react slower (16 h). Other azoles (benzimidazole, pyrazole) can be also introduced under these conditions for the reaction with arylboronic acids. However, it requires longer time (Table 5). 4 Conclusion We developed copper catalyst based on copolymer of VI with VCL which showed high catalytic efficiency and recyclability in the click reaction using only 0.025 mol% Cu. We found that composition of copolymers has big influence on the catalytic activity of assemblies hence, optimal copolymer had 3:1 molar ratio of VCL and VI and was obtained by free radical copolymerization. This catalyst is also very active and recyclable in Chan-Lam coupling of boronic acids and azoles. These promising results show great potential of copper catalyst based on vinylimidazole-containing polymers in copper-catalyzed reactions. CRediT authorship contribution statement Alexander Yu. coredata.dc:description: A new catalytic system based on copper supported on poly(N-vinylimidazole-co-N-vinylcaprolactam) was investigated. Various compositions of copolymers were checked to compare their influence on the catalytic activity. Copolymer with 25 mol% of N-vinylimidazole and 75 mol% of N-vinylcaprolactam showed the best catalytic efficiency along with its recycling ability in the click reaction and Chan-Lam coupling.
coredata.dc:title: Efficient recyclable Cu-catalysts for click reaction and Chan-Lam coupling based on copolymers of N-vinylimidazole with N-vinylcaprolactam
